top_categories.workout_context: 67ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Waucheesi Bike Race's Appalachian mountains, Forest gravel forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 75 miles.
At Waucheesi Bike Race, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Waucheesi Bike Race. Train it until it feels boring.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Waucheesi Bike Race's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before March.
75 miles on appalachian gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
5,000ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Waucheesi Bike Race, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
5,000ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Low-cadence force work for 5,000ft of climbing. The slow, grinding ascents where you can't spin—you push.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on appalachian gravel. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Waucheesi Bike Race’s 75 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Waucheesi Bike Race requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on appalachian gravel to build confidence. Expect: appalachian mountains, forest gravel, regional event.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and Over Under to prepare you for 75 miles of appalachian gravel in Tellico Plains, Tennessee.
